Please note: Those who have recovered and no more than 60 days have passed since receiving a recovery certificate - are exempt from isolation. As from 9th May, COVID-19 travel restrictions will be relaxed. Countries will no longer be classified as Red or Dark Red. This means that the travel ban for countries previously on the Dark Red list is no longer in force.     Travel to Malta now only requires any of the below:  - a recognised valid vaccine certificate   - a recognised valid COVID-19 recovery certificate   - a negative PCR test taken not more than 72 hrs before arrival   - a negative Rapid test taken not more than 24 hrs prior to arrival.     If one fails to present any one of these documents, they must undergo a 10-day mandatory quarantine, which can be reduced to 7 days following a negative test.     Children aged 6 or less are exempt from presenting any of these documents.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220513105703/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/malta-further-relaxes-its-covid-19-travel-restrictions/  http://web.archive.org/web/20220513110347/https://legislation.mt/eli/ln/2022/123/eng

Only those who test positive for COVID-19 will have to isolate. People who live with a COVID-19 patient no longer have to quarantine, unless they show symptoms of the virus. Primary contacts, even those unvaccinated, also no longer need to quarantine. Positive cases of COVID-19 must quarantine for 1 week, after which they can exit upon proof of a negative test, or remain in quarantine for 10 days total.
